Package org.wmn4j.notation

Class Pitch

java.lang.Object
org.wmn4j.notation.Pitch
All Implemented Interfaces:
Comparable<Pitch>
public final class Pitch extends Object implements Comparable<Pitch>
Represents a pitch. Pitches consist of the basic pitch letter Pitch.Base, accidentals, and octave number which tells the octave of the note. Octave number is based on scientific pitch notation.

This class is immutable.

      public static Pitch of(Pitch.Base pitchName, Pitch.Accidental accidental, int octave)
      Returns an instance.
      Parameters:
      pitchName - the letter on which the name of the pitch is based
      accidental - the accidental to use or natural if this pitch is not sharp or flat
      octave - the octave of the pitch
      Returns:
      Pitch object with the specified attributes
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if octave is negative or larger than MAX_OCTAVE.

    • toInt

      public int toInt()
      Get an integer representation of this pitch. This is the MIDI number of the pitch (middle-C, C4, being 60). A pitch is transformed into an integer using the formula pitchAsInteger = base + alter + (octave + 1) * 12 , where base is defined by the letter in the pitch name: C = 0, D = 2, E = 4, F = 5, G = 7, A = 9, B = 11. Alter is the number of sharps, or the number of flats * -1. For example, C#4 = 0 + 1 + 5 * 12 = 61 and Db4 = 2 - 1 + 5 * 12 = 61.
      Returns:
      this Pitch as an integer.

    • getPitchClass

      public PitchClass getPitchClass()

    • toString

    • equals

      public boolean equals(Object o)
      Returns true if this pitch is equal to the given object. Two pitches are equal if they have the same base letter, alteration (sharps or flats), and same octave. Pitches that are enharmonically equal but spelt differently are not equal. For example, C#4 != Db4.
      Overrides:
      equals in class Object
      Parameters:
      o - Object against which this is compared for equality.
      Returns:
      true if Object o is of class Pitch and has the same, pitch base, alterations, and octave as this.

    • compareTo

      public int compareTo(Pitch other)
      Returns an integer that denotes if this pitch is higher than, lower than, or equal to the given pitch.
      Specified by:
      compareTo in interface Comparable<Pitch>
      Parameters:
      other - the pitch with which this is compared
      Returns:
      negative integer if this is lower than other, positive integer if this is higher than other, 0 if pitches are (enharmonically) of same height
